title: How the rich invest: Ori Allon's investment trick is to stick to what you know
text:
What do you look at when investing in companies?

The evaluation varies depending on the stage of the company's growth. Later stage companies have evidence of business progress so the management team, implementation, ability to scale are all considered. Whereas in seed and early stage companies, it's more the team than the idea. Often there is limited data or metrics to rely on, so you have to believe in the team and management.

How do you measure the value of a non-income producing growth company?

Revenue is not the only metric to value a company. A dedicated user base or useful technology also make a business an appealing acquisition target. For example the $US19 billion acquisition of WhatsApp. The largest value add was its increasing market penetration, which as the user base grows the app becomes indispensable.

Do you think we are in a fintech bubble?

There are plenty of stocks trading on hefty multiples.

Do you think value investing will make a comeback?

Regardless of the strategy, to ensure success, investing takes patience. Be prepared to hold on to it for 10 years.

Best bit of advice you can give someone with $50,000 to invest?

Invest in what you know and are confident in and be prepared to hold on to it for five to 10 years for significant gains. Invest in companies and products that you use every day. Personally I invest in tech, S & P 500 and QQQ.
description: Tech entrepreneur Ori Allon is one of a handful of people to feature on both the Financial Review Rich List and Young Rich List and says revenue is not the only metric to value a company.
